document.masterDocTitle: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Limosina caenosa
Rondani, 1880: 36
( lectotype ♂ , MZUF, not examined).

Leptocera caenosa
.—
Roháček et al ., 2001: 151
(World catalog).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Leptocera fontinalis
auctt., nec ( Fallén, 1826 ): many older Nearctic references (see under
L. fontinalis
, Taxonomy).

Description . This species was redescribed and illustrated in detail by Roháček (1982) . Body length 2.1–3.5 mm . Medium brown with anterior part of frons, lower part of face (sometimes), inner surface of pedicel, basomedial area of first flagellomere and part of gena more or less reddish or yellow; palpus, inner surface of fore coxa, mid trochanter, knees, apices of tibiae, base of fore tibia and tarsi paler brown. Uppermost orbital setula inclinate and proclinate (sometimes absent on one side). Arista long-pubescent ( Fig. 6 ). Palpus inflated, only about 3.5x as long as wide. Mid tibia with bristle above distal dorsal 0.4–0.6x as long as distal anterodorsal bristle; lowermost bristle of proximal posterodorsal series shorter than lowermost bristle of anterodorsal series; posteroapical bristles short and usually of equal length, ventral one sometimes longer. Segments 3–5 of fore tarsus dilated in male, normal in female.

Male terminalia ( Figs. 48–51 ): Sternite 5 with many long bristles posterolaterally; posteromedial field of microtrichia wide but not very long; hind margin with numerous short and very fine, hair-like scales. Epandrium with numerous long bristles ventrally (see also Roháček, 1982 : Fig. 60 ). Anterior section of surstylus with anterior process terminating in a tapered, anteriorly directed point (sometimes directed somewhat laterally and then appearing more blunt; see Roháček, 1982 : Fig. 62 ); ventral lobe nearly flat and almost bristleless except for a few short hairs near inner margin, its long posterior bristle shifted forward and removed from hind margin (less than in the related
L. erratica
sp.n. ). Posterior section of surstylus of unusual shape: slender, tapered and curved inward almost rectangularly (posterior view), inner margin sclerotized throughout, without membranous margin (unlike most South American species), apical third with three strong bristles, middle one the strongest (all with pointed tips but lateral one less tapered), basal portion with few long, pale hairs in lateral half. Cercus simple (i.e., without finger-like or lamellate medial process). Postgonite with relatively small posterobasal notch (cf. Roháček, 1982 : Fig. 63 ).

Female terminalia ( Figs. 52–54 ): Tergite 7 moderately long and convex (length smaller than in South American species), with a pair of strong, cruciate bristles near middle, shining median stripe variable, extending from hind margin to somewhere between anterior margin and apex of anterior 2/3 ( one female each from Panama and Chile have the tergite completely pruinose; they were identified as
L. caenosa
because of their association with males). Sternite 7 simple, with pale hind margin. Fused tergite 10 + cerci moderately short (longer than in South American species), with short hairs. Spermathecae elongate, with transversely ridged basal half and slightly dilated, bumpy distal half.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 48–54 .
Leptocera caenosa
(48–51: Ecuador, 52–54: U.S.A.). Male terminalia (phallus and postgonites omitted): (48) posterior; (49) sternite 5; (50) surstylus, lateral; (51) ventral. Female terminalia: (52) dorsal; (53) spermathecae; (54) ventral. ce—cercus, sa—shining area of tergite 7.

subSubSection.paragraph:

TRISTAN DA CUNHA (new record): 1 ♀ , Sandy Point,
120 ft
,

21.ii.2005
, farmland, grass and odd pine trees, C. Hänel ( DEBU ); 1 ♀ , west of Edinburgh Village ,
127 ft
,

7–12.ii.2005
, cultivated crop land, C. Hänel ( DEBU ); 1 ♀ , on path below rim between Plantation and Council Gulches,
1,267 ft
,
10–14.ii.2005
, C. Hänel ( DEBU ). In addition we have seen specimens from Hawaii (Maui: DEBU ), Spain ( DEBU ), Hungary ( DEBU ), Russia (Siberia, Altai region : DEBU ), Japan ( DEBU ), South Africa (Natal: DEBU ), Australia (C. T ., N.S. W., Tasmania, Victoria : DEBU , CNCI , ANIC ) and New Zealand ( NZAC )
.

Distribution .
Leptocera caenosa
has been recorded from all biogeographic Regions except the Oriental (
Roháček et al ., 2001
). It is widespread in the Nearctic (Map 1) and the Palaearctic Region (not yet found in North Africa or the Middle East). Interestingly, the species seems to be quite rare in South America where most of its closest relatives occur. We strongly suspect that its occurrence in the Neotropical region (Central and South America) as well as Australasia (eastern Australia , New Zealand ), and several remote islands (Hawaii, Juan Fernández Is., South Shetlands, Tristan da Cunha , Gough I.) is due to accidental introduction, which is not surprising considering the synanthropic tendencies of this species (see Biology section under
L. caenosa
species group).

Discussion . In the male sex this species is easily recognised by the characteristic, slender and curved posterior section of the surstylus.
Leptocera caenosa
belongs to a group of species (including
L. erratica
sp.n. and
L. mendozana
) with simple male cercus and inclinate uppermost orbital setula. With
L. erratica
sp.n. it shares the inflated palpus, with
L. mendozana
the presence of three (instead of the usual two) strong apical bristles on the posterior section of the surstylus. The convexity and length of female tergite 7 is intermediate between
L. erythrocera
/
L. sphaerotheca
sp.n. (T7 short, hardly convex) on one hand and the endemic South American species (
L. argentinica
sp.n. ,
L. gongylotheca
sp.n. ,
L. mendozana Richards
,
L. papallacta
sp.n. ,
L. neocurvinervis Richards
,
L. aequilimbata Duda
,
L. longilimbata
sp.n. : T7 long, strongly convex) on the other hand. Females with completely pruinose tergite 7 cannot be separated from
L. erratica
sp.n.
